description: ENHANCED semantic memory for ORDERS table - optimized for natural language semantic search

enhancements.common_questions: How users actually phrase their questions

chunks.text:
TABLE: orders

DESCRIPTION: Records all customer purchase transactions and order information.

NATURAL_LANGUAGE_TERMS: orders, order table, purchases, transactions, sales, customer orders, purchase orders, order records, sales records, order history, purchase history, customer purchases, order data, transaction data, shopping orders

PRIMARY_KEY: order_id

FOREIGN_KEYS: customer_id → customers.customer_id

REFERENCED_BY: order_items.order_id, payment_transactions.order_id, shipments.order_id

USAGE: Order tracking, purchase history, sales analysis, revenue calculations, order management, find orders, customer order history, sales reporting, order fulfillment, transaction tracking

COMMON_QUERIES: Customer order history, orders by status, sales reports, order totals, monthly revenue, recent orders, pending orders, delivered orders, cancelled orders

USE_CASES: Track customer orders, view order history, check order status, calculate revenue, sales analysis, order fulfillment, delivery tracking, customer service

COLUMN: orders.order_id

DESCRIPTION: Unique identifier for each customer order.

NATURAL_LANGUAGE_TERMS: order id, order ID, order number, order identifier, purchase id, transaction id, order reference, order reference number, confirmation number, order code, unique order id, order key

DATA_TYPE: INTEGER

CONSTRAINTS: PRIMARY KEY, NOT NULL, AUTO-INCREMENT

REFERENCED_BY: order_items.order_id, payment_transactions.order_id, shipments.order_id

USAGE: Order identification, order tracking, find specific order, order lookup, joining with line items, order confirmation, unique order identification, transaction tracking

USE_CASES: Get order details, lookup order by ID, find specific order, track order, order confirmation lookup, order reference, retrieve order information

EXAMPLES:

- Order details: SELECT * FROM orders WHERE order_id = 3001

- Order items: SELECT * FROM order_items WHERE order_id = 3001

- Complete order info: FROM orders o JOIN order_items oi ON o.order_id = oi.order_id WHERE o.order_id = 3001

- With payment: FROM orders o JOIN payment_transactions pt ON o.order_id = pt.order_id WHERE o.order_id = 3001

BUSINESS_RULE: Unique order confirmation number displayed to customers. Immutable once assigned.

COMMON_QUESTIONS: What is my order number? Find order by ID? Track order number? Get order details? Order confirmation number? Lookup order reference?

COLUMN: orders.customer_id

DESCRIPTION: Links order to customer who placed it.

NATURAL_LANGUAGE_TERMS: customer id, customer ID, customer identifier, who ordered, which customer, customer reference, buyer id, purchaser id, order placed by, customer who bought, user id

DATA_TYPE: INTEGER

CONSTRAINTS: FOREIGN KEY, NOT NULL

REFERENCES: customers.customer_id

USAGE: Customer order history, find orders by customer, joining orders with customer info, customer lifetime value, orders per customer, customer purchase history, who placed order

USE_CASES: Customer order history, find customer's orders, orders by specific customer, customer purchase tracking, link order to customer, who bought this

EXAMPLES:

- Customer orders: SELECT * FROM orders WHERE customer_id = 1001 ORDER BY order_date DESC

- With customer details: FROM customers c JOIN orders o ON c.customer_id = o.customer_id WHERE c.customer_id = 1001

- Customer spending: SELECT customer_id, SUM(total_amount) FROM orders GROUP BY customer_id

- Orders per customer: SELECT customer_id, COUNT(*) FROM orders GROUP BY customer_id

BUSINESS_RULE: Every order belongs to exactly one customer. One customer can have many orders (1:N relationship).

COMMON_QUESTIONS: Show customer orders? Which customer placed this order? Find orders by customer? Customer order history? Who ordered this? Customer purchase history?

COLUMN: orders.order_date

DESCRIPTION: Timestamp when order was placed by customer.

NATURAL_LANGUAGE_TERMS: order date, order time, when ordered, purchase date, order timestamp, date ordered, time ordered, when placed, purchase time, order created, order placed, transaction date, date of order, order creation date

DATA_TYPE: TIMESTAMP

FORMAT: ISO 8601 (YYYY-MM-DD HH:MM:SS)

USAGE: Date filtering, find orders by date, recent orders, sales reports by period, trend analysis, orders this month, orders today, date range filtering, time-based analysis

USE_CASES: Recent orders, orders this month, orders today, find orders by date range, sales by period, monthly sales, daily orders, order timeline

EXAMPLES:

- Today's orders: SELECT * FROM orders WHERE DATE(order_date) = CURRENT_DATE

- Last 30 days: WHERE order_date >= CURRENT_DATE - INTERVAL '30 days'

- Date range: WHERE order_date BETWEEN '2024-01-01' AND '2024-01-31'

- Monthly sales: SELECT DATE_TRUNC('month', order_date) AS month, COUNT(*) FROM orders GROUP BY month ORDER BY month

- Recent orders: ORDER BY order_date DESC LIMIT 10

BUSINESS_RULE: Timestamp when customer placed order, not delivery date. Use for time-series sales analysis.

COMMON_QUESTIONS: Show recent orders? Orders today? Orders this month? Find orders by date? When was order placed? Orders in date range? Sales this month?

COLUMN: orders.total_amount

DESCRIPTION: Total value of order in US dollars.

NATURAL_LANGUAGE_TERMS: total amount, order total, total cost, total price, order value, purchase amount, order amount, how much, total paid, order cost, grand total, total spent, order price, transaction amount, sale amount

DATA_TYPE: DECIMAL(10,2)

CONSTRAINTS: NOT NULL, total_amount > 0

CURRENCY: USD

CALCULATION: Sum of all order_items.total_price for this order_id

USAGE: Revenue calculations, order value filtering, find expensive orders, average order value, customer lifetime value, sales totals, revenue analysis, financial reports

USE_CASES: Calculate total revenue, find large orders, average order value, order value filtering, customer spending, sales analysis, revenue by period

EXAMPLES:

- Large orders: SELECT * FROM orders WHERE total_amount > 500

- Value range: WHERE total_amount BETWEEN 100 AND 500

- Total revenue: SELECT SUM(total_amount) FROM orders WHERE order_status != 'Cancelled'

- Average order: SELECT AVG(total_amount) FROM orders WHERE order_status != 'Cancelled'

- Monthly revenue: SELECT DATE_TRUNC('month', order_date), SUM(total_amount) FROM orders GROUP BY 1

BUSINESS_RULE: Equals sum of order_items.total_price. Exclude cancelled orders in revenue calculations. Does not include tax or shipping.

COMMON_QUESTIONS: What is order total? How much is order? Total order value? Calculate total revenue? Average order value? Order amount? Find expensive orders? Total sales?

COLUMN: orders.payment_method

DESCRIPTION: Method used for payment.

NATURAL_LANGUAGE_TERMS: payment method, payment type, how paid, payment option, paid with, payment mode, method of payment, payment channel, payment way, how customer paid, payment used

DATA_TYPE: VARCHAR(50)

VALID_VALUES: Credit Card, Debit Card, PayPal

USAGE: Payment method analysis, filter by payment type, payment preferences, payment method distribution, payment analytics, how customers pay

USE_CASES: Filter orders by payment method, payment type analysis, credit card orders, PayPal orders, payment method preferences, payment distribution

EXAMPLES:

- Credit card orders: SELECT * FROM orders WHERE payment_method = 'Credit Card'

- Method distribution: SELECT payment_method, COUNT(*) FROM orders GROUP BY payment_method

- PayPal orders: WHERE payment_method = 'PayPal'

- Revenue by method: SELECT payment_method, SUM(total_amount) FROM orders GROUP BY payment_method

BUSINESS_RULE: Must match payment_transactions.payment_method. Three valid payment options.

COMMON_QUESTIONS: How did customer pay? Payment method used? Credit card orders? PayPal transactions? Filter by payment type? Payment method distribution?

COLUMN: orders.order_status

DESCRIPTION: Current fulfillment status of order.

NATURAL_LANGUAGE_TERMS: order status, status, order state, fulfillment status, delivery status, where is order, order progress, current status, processing status, shipped, delivered, cancelled, pending, in transit

DATA_TYPE: VARCHAR(50)

VALID_VALUES: Processing, In Transit, Delivered, Cancelled

STATUS_FLOW: Processing → In Transit → Delivered (normal flow), or Processing → Cancelled

USAGE: Order tracking, status filtering, fulfillment tracking, delivery monitoring, find pending orders, completed orders, cancelled orders, orders in progress

USE_CASES: Track order status, find delivered orders, pending orders, cancelled orders, orders in transit, fulfillment monitoring, delivery status check

EXAMPLES:

- Delivered orders: SELECT * FROM orders WHERE order_status = 'Delivered'

- Active orders: WHERE order_status IN ('Processing', 'In Transit')

- Needs attention: WHERE order_status = 'Processing' AND order_date < CURRENT_DATE - INTERVAL '3 days'

- Status count: SELECT order_status, COUNT(*) FROM orders GROUP BY order_status

- Completed orders: WHERE order_status = 'Delivered'

BUSINESS_RULE: Processing=confirmed awaiting shipment, In Transit=shipped out, Delivered=completed successfully, Cancelled=terminated. Exclude cancelled from revenue.

COMMON_QUESTIONS: What is order status? Where is my order? Show delivered orders? Pending orders? Cancelled orders? Orders in transit? Track order? Order shipped? Is order delivered?

COLUMN: orders.shipping_address

DESCRIPTION: Street address for order delivery.

NATURAL_LANGUAGE_TERMS: shipping address, delivery address, ship to address, where shipping, delivery location, shipping location, send to address, delivery street, shipping street, where delivered

DATA_TYPE: VARCHAR(100)

USAGE: Shipping label generation, delivery address display, where order ships to, delivery location, address analysis

USE_CASES: Get shipping address, where to deliver, delivery location, shipping destination, order delivery address

EXAMPLES:

- Orders to address: SELECT * FROM orders WHERE shipping_address LIKE '%Main Street%'

- Delivery locations: SELECT DISTINCT shipping_address FROM orders

BUSINESS_RULE: May differ from customer's primary address. Complete address requires city, state, zip.

COMMON_QUESTIONS: Where is order shipping? Delivery address? Where to ship? Shipping location? Order delivery address?

COLUMN: orders.shipping_city

DESCRIPTION: City for order delivery.

NATURAL_LANGUAGE_TERMS: shipping city, delivery city, ship to city, city delivered to, delivery city name, shipping destination city, where shipping, city location

DATA_TYPE: VARCHAR(50)

USAGE: Delivery location analysis, regional shipping reports, orders by city, shipping destinations, city-based delivery analysis

USE_CASES: Orders shipped to city, delivery city analysis, shipping by city, orders to specific city, delivery destinations

EXAMPLES:

- Orders to city: SELECT * FROM orders WHERE shipping_city = 'New York'

- Orders by city: SELECT shipping_city, COUNT(*) FROM orders GROUP BY shipping_city ORDER BY COUNT(*) DESC

- City shipping volume: SELECT shipping_city, shipping_state, COUNT(*) FROM orders GROUP BY shipping_city, shipping_state

BUSINESS_RULE: Used with shipping_state and shipping_zip for complete delivery address.

COMMON_QUESTIONS: Orders shipped to New York? Delivery city? Where shipping? Orders by city? Which city has most deliveries?

COLUMN: orders.shipping_state

DESCRIPTION: US state code for order delivery.

NATURAL_LANGUAGE_TERMS: shipping state, delivery state, ship to state, state code, delivery state code, shipping region, where shipping, state delivered to, destination state

DATA_TYPE: VARCHAR(2)

FORMAT: Two-letter uppercase state codes

VALID_VALUES: CA, NY, TX, FL, IL, WA, OR, etc. (all 50 US states)

USAGE: Regional shipping analysis, orders by state, tax calculation, delivery zone determination, state-level shipping reports

USE_CASES: Orders shipped to California, delivery by state, state shipping analysis, regional delivery patterns, orders to specific state

EXAMPLES:

- Orders to California: SELECT * FROM orders WHERE shipping_state = 'CA'

- Orders by state: SELECT shipping_state, COUNT(*) FROM orders GROUP BY shipping_state ORDER BY COUNT(*) DESC

- State revenue: SELECT shipping_state, SUM(total_amount) FROM orders GROUP BY shipping_state

BUSINESS_RULE: Two-letter USPS codes. Used for tax and shipping calculations.

COMMON_QUESTIONS: Orders shipped to California? Deliveries by state? Which state gets most orders? Orders to Texas? Shipping to NY?

COLUMN: orders.shipping_zip

DESCRIPTION: Zip code for order delivery.

NATURAL_LANGUAGE_TERMS: shipping zip, delivery zip, zip code, postal code, shipping zip code, delivery postal code, delivery zone, zip area

DATA_TYPE: VARCHAR(10)

FORMAT: 5-digit or 9-digit US postal codes

USAGE: Precise delivery routing, shipping cost calculation, zone mapping, delivery zip analysis

USE_CASES: Orders to zip code, delivery zone analysis, shipping by zip, zip code patterns

EXAMPLES:

- Orders to zip: SELECT * FROM orders WHERE shipping_zip = '90210'

- Zip pattern: WHERE shipping_zip LIKE '902%'

- Orders by zip: SELECT shipping_zip, COUNT(*) FROM orders GROUP BY shipping_zip

BUSINESS_RULE: US postal codes. Combines with city and state for complete delivery address.

COMMON_QUESTIONS: Orders to zip code? Deliveries by zip? Shipping to postal code?

RELATIONSHIP: orders to customers (Many-to-One)

DESCRIPTION: Each order belongs to one customer. Customer can have many orders.

NATURAL_LANGUAGE_TERMS: order customer, who ordered, customer orders, order belongs to customer, customer purchases, order placed by, customer order history

JOIN_CONDITION: orders.customer_id = customers.customer_id

CARDINALITY: N:1 (many orders can belong to one customer)

FOREIGN_KEY: orders.customer_id references customers.customer_id

USAGE: Get customer who placed order, customer order history, customer details with order, who bought this, customer purchase tracking

USE_CASES: Find who placed order, customer order history, customer details for order, link order to customer, customer purchase analysis

EXAMPLES:

- Order with customer: SELECT o.order_id, c.first_name, c.last_name, c.email, o.order_date, o.total_amount FROM orders o JOIN customers c ON o.customer_id = c.customer_id WHERE o.order_id = 3001

- Customer order history: SELECT c.email, o.order_id, o.order_date, o.total_amount FROM customers c JOIN orders o ON c.customer_id = o.customer_id WHERE c.customer_id = 1001 ORDER BY o.order_date DESC

- Customer lifetime value: SELECT c.customer_id, c.email, COUNT(o.order_id) AS order_count, SUM(o.total_amount) AS total_spent FROM customers c JOIN orders o ON c.customer_id = o.customer_id GROUP BY c.customer_id, c.email

BUSINESS_RULE: Every order must have valid customer_id. One customer can have many orders.

COMMON_QUESTIONS: Who placed this order? Customer order history? Get customer details for order? Which customer made purchase?

RELATIONSHIP: orders to order_items (One-to-Many)

DESCRIPTION: One order contains many line items (products). This is the order detail breakdown.

NATURAL_LANGUAGE_TERMS: order items, order details, order line items, what's in order, order contents, items in order, products in order, order breakdown, shopping cart, what customer bought

JOIN_CONDITION: orders.order_id = order_items.order_id

CARDINALITY: 1:N (one order has one or many line items)

FOREIGN_KEY: order_items.order_id references orders.order_id

USAGE: Get order details, items in order, order breakdown, what customer bought, order contents, itemized order, shopping cart contents

USE_CASES: Show order details, items in order, order breakdown, what's in cart, order line items, complete order view, itemized order

EXAMPLES:

- Items in order: SELECT o.order_id, o.order_date, oi.product_id, oi.quantity, oi.unit_price, oi.total_price FROM orders o JOIN order_items oi ON o.order_id = oi.order_id WHERE o.order_id = 3001

- Complete order: SELECT o.*, oi.* FROM orders o JOIN order_items oi ON o.order_id = oi.order_id WHERE o.order_id = 3001

- Order item count: SELECT o.order_id, COUNT(oi.order_item_id) AS item_count FROM orders o JOIN order_items oi ON o.order_id = oi.order_id GROUP BY o.order_id

BUSINESS_RULE: Every order must have at least one line item. Order total equals sum of line item totals.

COMMON_QUESTIONS: What's in order? Show order details? Items in order? Order breakdown? What did customer buy? Order line items?

RELATIONSHIP: orders to payment_transactions (One-to-One)

DESCRIPTION: Each order has one payment transaction record.

NATURAL_LANGUAGE_TERMS: order payment, payment for order, order transaction, payment details, how order was paid, payment information, transaction details

JOIN_CONDITION: orders.order_id = payment_transactions.order_id

CARDINALITY: 1:1 (one order has one payment)

FOREIGN_KEY: payment_transactions.order_id references orders.order_id

USAGE: Get payment details for order, payment information, transaction details, how order was paid, payment verification

USE_CASES: Show payment details, payment information for order, transaction details, payment verification, how customer paid

EXAMPLES:

- Order with payment: SELECT o.order_id, o.total_amount, pt.payment_method, pt.transaction_id, pt.payment_status FROM orders o JOIN payment_transactions pt ON o.order_id = pt.order_id WHERE o.order_id = 3001

BUSINESS_RULE: One order has exactly one payment transaction.

COMMON_QUESTIONS: Payment details for order? How was order paid? Transaction information? Payment status?

QUERY USE CASE: Track orders by status

DESCRIPTION: Find orders in specific fulfillment stages for tracking and management.

NATURAL_LANGUAGE_QUERIES: pending orders, delivered orders, cancelled orders, orders in transit, processing orders, shipped orders, where is order, order status, completed orders, active orders

TABLES_USED: orders

WHEN_TO_USE: Order fulfillment tracking, delivery monitoring, order management, customer service, status filtering

SQL_PATTERN: SELECT * FROM orders WHERE order_status = 'status_value'

EXAMPLES:

- Delivered orders: SELECT * FROM orders WHERE order_status = 'Delivered'

- Pending orders: WHERE order_status = 'Processing'

- Active orders: WHERE order_status IN ('Processing', 'In Transit')

- Cancelled orders: WHERE order_status = 'Cancelled'

- Delayed processing: WHERE order_status = 'Processing' AND order_date < CURRENT_DATE - INTERVAL '3 days'

- Status distribution: SELECT order_status, COUNT(*) FROM orders GROUP BY order_status

BUSINESS_RULE: Exclude cancelled orders from revenue. Active orders are Processing or In Transit.

COMMON_QUESTIONS: Show pending orders? Delivered orders? Where is my order? Cancelled orders? Orders being processed? Shipped orders? Order status?

QUERY USE CASE: Find recent orders

DESCRIPTION: Get orders from specific time periods for analysis and reporting.

NATURAL_LANGUAGE_QUERIES: recent orders, orders today, orders this month, orders this week, latest orders, new orders, orders yesterday, orders last 7 days, orders last 30 days

TABLES_USED: orders

WHEN_TO_USE: Recent order monitoring, daily sales reports, period analysis, trend tracking

SQL_PATTERNS:

- Today: SELECT * FROM orders WHERE DATE(order_date) = CURRENT_DATE

- This month: WHERE DATE_TRUNC('month', order_date) = DATE_TRUNC('month', CURRENT_DATE)

- Last N days: WHERE order_date >= CURRENT_DATE - INTERVAL 'N days'

EXAMPLES:

- Orders today: SELECT * FROM orders WHERE DATE(order_date) = CURRENT_DATE ORDER BY order_date DESC

- Last 7 days: SELECT * FROM orders WHERE order_date >= CURRENT_DATE - INTERVAL '7 days'

- This month: SELECT * FROM orders WHERE order_date >= DATE_TRUNC('month', CURRENT_DATE)

- Recent orders: SELECT * FROM orders ORDER BY order_date DESC LIMIT 20

BUSINESS_RULE: Use order_date for when order was placed, not delivery date.

COMMON_QUESTIONS: Show recent orders? Orders today? This month's orders? Last week orders? Latest orders? New orders?

QUERY USE CASE: Calculate revenue and sales

DESCRIPTION: Analyze total sales, revenue, and financial performance.

NATURAL_LANGUAGE_QUERIES: total revenue, total sales, monthly revenue, daily sales, revenue by period, sales performance, how much revenue, total income, sales total, revenue analysis

TABLES_USED: orders

WHEN_TO_USE: Financial reporting, sales analysis, revenue tracking, performance metrics, business analytics

SQL_PATTERN: SELECT SUM(total_amount) FROM orders WHERE order_status != 'Cancelled'

EXAMPLES:

- Total revenue: SELECT SUM(total_amount) AS total_revenue FROM orders WHERE order_status != 'Cancelled'

- Monthly revenue: SELECT DATE_TRUNC('month', order_date) AS month, SUM(total_amount) AS revenue FROM orders WHERE order_status != 'Cancelled' GROUP BY month ORDER BY month

- Daily sales: SELECT DATE(order_date) AS day, SUM(total_amount) AS daily_sales FROM orders GROUP BY day ORDER BY day DESC

- Average order value: SELECT AVG(total_amount) FROM orders WHERE order_status != 'Cancelled'

- Revenue by state: SELECT shipping_state, SUM(total_amount) FROM orders GROUP BY shipping_state ORDER BY SUM(total_amount) DESC

BUSINESS_RULE: Always exclude cancelled orders from revenue calculations.

COMMON_QUESTIONS: What is total revenue? Monthly sales? Daily revenue? Average order value? Sales this month? Total income?

QUERY USE CASE: Get customer order history

DESCRIPTION: Find all orders placed by specific customer with details.

NATURAL_LANGUAGE_QUERIES: customer order history, customer orders, what customer bought, customer purchases, purchase history, order history, customer shopping history, past orders

TABLES_USED: orders, customers

WHEN_TO_USE: Customer service, order lookup, purchase history, customer analysis, support inquiries

SQL_PATTERN: SELECT * FROM orders WHERE customer_id = X ORDER BY order_date DESC

EXAMPLES:

- Customer orders: SELECT o.order_id, o.order_date, o.total_amount, o.order_status FROM orders o WHERE o.customer_id = 1001 ORDER BY o.order_date DESC

- With customer details: SELECT c.first_name, c.last_name, o.order_id, o.order_date, o.total_amount FROM customers c JOIN orders o ON c.customer_id = o.customer_id WHERE c.customer_id = 1001 ORDER BY o.order_date DESC

- Order count: SELECT customer_id, COUNT(*) AS order_count FROM orders GROUP BY customer_id ORDER BY order_count DESC

- Customer spending: SELECT customer_id, SUM(total_amount) AS total_spent FROM orders WHERE order_status != 'Cancelled' GROUP BY customer_id

BUSINESS_RULE: Order by date descending to show most recent first.

COMMON_QUESTIONS: Show customer order history? What did customer buy? Customer purchases? Past orders? Customer shopping history? Order history?
